awd_titl_txt: CRCNS US-German Research Proposal: Origin of distributed modular activity in the neocortex
awd_abstract_narration:
In the brain, early developmental events define and constrain its future capabilities and functions. Large-scale cortical networks are critical to the processing of information in the brain, yet very little is known about how such networks arise in early development. This project will address this critical question by creating an interdisciplinary collaboration that will develop and then test novel computational models of neural activity in the early cortex. These models will aim to describe the mechanisms through which functional neural networks arise in the early cortex, thereby providing critical new insights into brain development. Furthermore, this project will employ cutting edge optical approaches to measure and manipulate networks in the developing cortex, providing a direct test of these models. This project will produce novel computational tools and unique large-scale imaging datasets of the early brain that will be valuable to the broad scientific community, while also providing key training for junior scientists in the tight integration of theory and experiment. Collectively, this project will yield new insights into fundamental questions of functional brain development and generate novel tools and datasets for future research. 

Cortical activity in primates and carnivores is both modular (columnar) and distributed, linking functional units that are spread across cortical space. Computational models suggest that these two properties can arise from local network interactions in the early developing cortex, however both critical aspects of the proposed mechanisms and experimental validation are currently lacking. In order to address this key gap in the understanding of cortical network development, this project will combine computational modeling with highly sensitive calcium imaging and pharmacological and optogenetic methods for up-and down-regulating specific circuit components. This research will derive critical predictions for the effects of experimental manipulations of local network components on modular and distributed cortical activity and then perform these manipulations in vivo to test the validity of the proposed mechanisms. This work will greatly deepen the understanding of the origin of modular and distributed activity in the early developing cortex, while addressing long-standing issues in the field by identifying the cortical mechanism for generating modular activity and testing whether long-range network correlations can arise from local recurrent connections as a truly emergent property. By combining state of the art experimental approaches, data analysis, and theoretical modeling, this project will yield a quantitative understanding of the mechanisms that give rise in the young brain to two of the most prominent features of cortical activity. 

A companion project is being funded by the Federal Ministry of Education and Research, Germany (BMBF).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Sensory perception and behavior require the coordinated activity of tens of thousands of neurons functioning together in large-scale networks. Understanding how such networks form during development is therefore essential to understanding how they function, in both health and disease. In this project, we formed a trans-national collaboration between experimental neuroscientists at the University of Minnesota (UMN) and theoretical and computational neuroscientists at the Frankfurt Institute for Advanced Studies. Together, we developed new technologies and achieved key discoveries about the construction and function of neural networks.

First, at UMN, we designed, built, and validated a novel microscope which allows the simultaneous imaging of brain activity in animal models while also being able to directly manipulate the activity of those brain networks, all at large scale, spanning several millimeters and encompassing hundreds of thousands of neurons. This technology enables new experiments, in our laboratory and others, that can now directly test theories of neural network formation, plasticity, and function. We described our new microscope in scientific publications and made the full details of its construction freely available to the scientific community, thus enabling the rapid adoption of our technology and enhancing scientific discovery.

We then used this microscope to, for the first time, directly test the theory that the highly organized functional brain networks seen in the mature brain arise during development through self-organization. Self-organization is a powerful theory that describes how small-scale local interactions within a network can create large scale and emergent features, without any structured or organized inputs. This theory has broad applications across a wide range of disciplines including physics, astronomy, and ecology, but had never been directly tested in neural networks in the developing brain. By combining our new microscope technology with detailed computer models, we were able to make clear and testable predictions about how self-organizing networks should behave within the developing brain. We found that these networks, as predicted, act to transform uniform and unstructured inputs into highly ordered and structured outputs, directly demonstrating the self-organization of activity within the brain. We further showed that the exact transformations performed by the brain were constrained by the precise local structure within the network, verifying the predictions of our model. In addition to testing a long-held theory of brain development, this work demonstrated the power of self-organizing systems in building functional neural networks, which has clear implications for the design of next-generation algorithms for artificial intelligence.

In addition, by imaging neural activity in a wide variety of brain regions, including both those that primarily process sensory information (visual, auditory, somatosensory (touch)), as well as those that are involved in higher order functions like planning goal-directed behaviors, we found that the same large-scale network architecture exists throughout the brain during early development. This highly surprising result suggests that the brain is much more ‘generic’ in its early structure than previously thought, with the specialized functions of different brain regions emerging later in development. We went on to show that this early shared organization progresses through a largely similar pattern of maturation over a key period of development when animals transition to begin responding to external sensory stimuli. Strikingly, the organization of all of these brain areas was highly similar to that seen when we directly tested for self-organization as described above. This implies that these same self-organizing interactions are a universal feature of the developing brain that guide the formation of functional brain networks throughout very different brain regions. This further suggests that any perturbation or disruption to these self-organizing interactions is likely to have profound consequences for development, which may underlie many neurodevelopmental disorders.

Collectively, this project generated 4 key scientific publications, novel technologies, and large datasets, all of which are freely available to the scientific community. This project provided training opportunities for multiple scientists at early career stages, furthering their development and progress towards independent scientific research. Finally, this project contributed to a deeper understanding of the mechanisms that are responsible for the generation of activity states in brain networks, which is fundamental knowledge that can serve as the basis for future work designing novel treatments for a host of neurodevelopmental disorders that impact large numbers of people.
